reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching was fine but lectures ppts were not upload to canvas on the first 5 to 6 lectures even students reflected that the ppts were not included(probably he is new to teach this course). Even a same content but different version ppt was given, sometimes was still hard to catch up and I do not understand the purpose of it.But the instructor is nice and be willing to teach when you have any difficulties.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading was probably the most restricted course in chemistry in ust, as getting a 40% mark can be at a range of C+ to B+ in other chemistry courses but not is this course and since the class has a small proportion of students it is more likely the deviation of students and grades are more separated which a few marks can affect a sub grade.
reviews.comment_workload: 5 assignments ,midterm, final exam and one final group presentation. Five mcs for each midterm and final exam plus around 10 LQs which include concepts of topic taught and mathematical solving. The workload is definitely heavy comparing to other chemistry electives but if you have more spare time, the assignment are actually helpful on understanding the topics taught and the professor is willing to help with assignments difficulties. But unfortunate as a year 4 student, I reg this class as it was told the workload is low and only mcs finals and midterms are included which was so different from the previous professor.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Lu is a passionate lecturer and always try to deliver his concept with some thesis written by himself. (He even use figures from a thesis as a question in the final exam)
Although his lectures are quite boring, he can explain the concepts in a clear way.
Prof Lu is also willing to answer questions about the assignment or the lecture content, no matter asking the questions after class or by email. Sometimes he nearly told us the answer to the assignment.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assessment
30% by 5 assignments
   Quite easy to get high marks on the assignments if you
   understand the concept or have some people to carry you.
20% midterm
30% final
   Both midterm and final are closed-book.
20% presentation
   Prof. Lu will give out a list of topics for us to choose from for the
   presentation. You can also request to do a new topic as long as
   he approves
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If you are below mean in some previous chem courses, this will be a nice choice for your free chem electives.
I got nearly full marks for the assignment, but below mean for 1.x sd in both mid-term and final exams. With the unknown marks for the presentation, I finally have a B-, so the grading is good if you are below mean.
Some of my friends got above mean for 1.x sd in both mt and final but only have a B+, probably the A range is hard to get (??
reviews.comment_workload:
The questions from the assignment are not straight forward, need some effort to finish.

If you have a nice groupmate (choose by yourself), the workload for your presentation is mild.

Reading material is not a must to read, but you can get some answers to the assignment from it.

Again, as there are sooooo many concepts introduced, the workload from revising exams will be heavy if you are a muggle like me.
Especially the final exam is CUMULATIVE (which means the concepts or questions from the midterm also appears in the final), so the RAM of my brain directly exploded during the final period ...

reviews.author: ustchem
reviews.title: Good course!!!
reviews.comment_content:
The course is divided into three parts:
1. fundamentals
    L1-2: symmetry and crystal structure (point group, space group)
    L3-4: representation of crystal structures (bcc, ccp, hcp; rock salt, zinc blende etc.)
    L5-6: bonding in solids, Pauling rule
    L7-8: band theory

2. synthesis & characterization
    L9-10: synthesis of solid-state and nano-material
    L11-12: structural characterization (XRD, structure factors)
    -optical characterization

3. properties & applications
    L13-14:  optical materials (electronic transition, photoluminescence-PL wavelength, FWHM, stoke shifts and PLQY)
    L15: spectroscopic methods (absorption and emission)
    L16-17: conducting materials (Fermi-Dirac distribution, relationship between band diagram and conductivity, doping
    L18-19: magnetic materials (paramagnetic, diamagnetic, antiferromagnetic, ferromagnetic, ferrimagnetic, Curie Law, superexchange interactions)
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Lu is quite nice, he is willing to answer the questions about the assignments and some deeper concepts. He sometimes provides in-class exercises which are useful for understanding the concepts.
reviews.comment_grading:
30% assignments (5 in total)
20% midterm (closed-bk)
30% final (closed-bk)
20% presentation (topic will be provided)

The time you spent is proportional to the grading!
reviews.comment_workload:
There will be one assignment after Prof. Lu finished four lectures (around 2 topics for each assignment), we have one week to finish the assignment and submit it in the lectures. Sometimes, it is hard to find the answer in the notes, you may need more time to think about it and do some research. Assignment is a good way for me to do revision.

Reading materials are uploaded to canvas, it is optional but I advised you to read them, they are useful for your assignments and exam.

reviews.comment_teaching:
I was really shocked when I attended the first lesson. I know I shouldn't expect that I could listen good pronunciation from chem dept prof, but she has really terrible accent and hesitation. Sometimes I dun even know which word she is reading.

And she just reads out what she has in the ppt. Even there is calculation-based question, she never explains them.

At the last lesson, her TAs are invited to give a lecture for us, and in my opinion the girl TA Beryl even teaches better lo

This course covers essential theoretical frameworks for environmental analysis, which is indeed inspiring. Especially I have worked in an environmental testing laboratory for few months. Of course, some content is outdated and not particularly useful in the real-world scenario. Still, I am happy to learn from Stefan’s lecture and solve some calculation problems.

As a matter of fact, part of the content of my course project is inspired by Stefan’s presentation. His presentation might seem unappealing at first glance because of messy slides and calm voice. But his elaboration does help you understand things broader, at least better than reading the slides alone.

One thing problematic, however, is that he is unable to manage the time well. He simply over-elaborates the first few topics, leaving insufficient time for the last few. So, a B for his imbalanced delivery.
